prompt: What makes an inductive argument strong?
options: The premises make the conclusion highly probable
The argument uses formal logic symbols
hint: Remember, inductive arguments never guarantee their conclusions.
explanation: A strong inductive argument is one where the premises make the conclusion highly probable (though never certain). Unlike deductive validity, inductive strength is a matter of degree - arguments can be stronger or weaker depending on how much support the premises provide.
visual_concept: Deductive: Steel bridge - if built right, it WILL hold. Inductive: Rope bridge - stronger ropes make it MORE likely to hold, but never guaranteed.
